Experience Site Reliability Engineer Dropbox August 2014  – Present (1 year 1 month) San Francisco Bay Area Technical lead of the team responsible for machine management, configuration management, AWS tooling and EC2 management, support services such as DNS and systems monitoring, and systems-level authentication and authorization across all of Dropbox's production infrastructure. Developer, Policy Editor, Technical Committee Member Debian November 2005  – Present (9 years 10 months) Debian Policy Editor since November of 2006. Debian Technical Committee member from January of 2009 to November of 2014. I participate in distribution-wide technical policy and design, and previously made substantial contributions to the Lintian package checking tool. I'm also a member of the Shibboleth, Perl, and NVIDIA packaging teams and assist when I have time. 
 
I also maintain Debian packages of most of the software I personally develop and attempt to assist with various packages I personally use. 
 
As a member of the Debian Technical Committee, I was part of the group that handles appeals and dispute resolution for technical issues within Debian. I did extensive research and analysis on init systems and was an active participant in Debian's evaluation of systemd, upstart, and other next-generation init systems. Technical Lead Stanford University March 2002  –  August 2014  (12 years 6 months) San Francisco Bay Area Lead systems administrator for the group responsible for campus authentication, directory, email, and distributed file system services for all of Stanford University. Was responsible, at one point or another, for every central service run by the group. 
 
We adopted a DevOps model for service management before it became popular, after too much first-hand experience with inefficiencies and imbalances in the development hand-off model. Our group was one of the first organizations to deploy Puppet broadly in production, and we worked closely with Luke Kanies on early data model and manifest syntax issues. 
 
Lead maintainer and developer of the campus Kerberos infrastructure, including contributing patches to both MIT Kerberos and Heimdal and maintaining KDC plugins for password strength checking and synchronization to Active Directory. Helped design the remctl protocol for simple, secure remote command execution in a Kerberos environment and then developed it into the middleware layer used for many system-to-system links and administrative tools at Stanford University and elsewhere. 
 
Build engineer and then lead developer of the WebAuth site-wide central web authentication system, on which most web security at Stanford University is based. Desgined and implemented support for multifactor authentication within the WebAuth framework and led the team responsible for deploying mandatory multifactor authentication for the entire Stanford user base. 
 
Successfully advocated adoption of Debian as the preferred Linux distribution for central IT services. Took over maintenance and development of Stanford's FAI-based Debian build system and designed our local repository and local packaging policies. Led the effort to package all local tools and locally-developed software as first-class Debian packages for proper integration with the rest of the operating system. Systems Administrator Stanford University April 1997  –  March 2002  (5 years) San Francisco Bay Area Maintained a site-wide software installation for, at varying times, SunOS, Solaris, ULTRIX, AIX, HP-UX, IRIX, Tru64, NeXTSTEP, and Linux. Wrote much of the supporting software to maintain a large-scale software installation of over 500 packages and many architectures in AFS. 
 
Maintained AFS file servers for the campus distributed file system and developed numerous tools and infrastructure to automate common AFS maintenance tasks. Many of those tools are still in use today at Stanford, and some have been adopted more broadly. 
 
Did other software development and systems administration on demand, including maintaining the campus Usenet servers, writing the log rotation and archiving software still in use by Stanford today, and maintaining the Solaris build system. Lead maintainer and developer of the campus Kerberos infrastructure, including contributing patches to both MIT Kerberos and Heimdal and maintaining KDC plugins for password strength checking and synchronization to Active Directory. Helped design the remctl protocol for simple, secure remote command execution in a Kerberos environment and then developed it into the middleware layer used for many system-to-system links and administrative tools at Stanford University and elsewhere. 
 
Build engineer and then lead developer of the WebAuth site-wide central web authentication system, on which most web security at Stanford University is based. Desgined and implemented support for multifactor authentication within the WebAuth framework and led the team responsible for deploying mandatory multifactor authentication for the entire Stanford user base. 
 
Successfully advocated adoption of Debian as the preferred Linux distribution for central IT services. Took over maintenance and development of Stanford's FAI-based Debian build system and designed our local repository and local packaging policies. Led the effort to package all local tools and locally-developed software as first-class Debian packages for proper integration with the rest of the operating system. Summary Expert in multiplayer online live music collaborations, engineer, producer, and performer of electronic music and vocal improvisation. I have created a social network, CYBERJAMMER.net, which provides information for musicians to set up their own online jam studio and find partners to jam live music with online via ultrafast internet.  
 
Learning to use this technology contributes to digital literacy by learning about computer networking, sending and receiving audio over the internet, collaboration, and more. 
 
Activities include website development, participant recruitment, music session curation, musical composition and production, community engagement, and outreach to anyone interested in setting up an online music studio, or participating in an online music jam.  
 
Specialties include: produced music, songwriting, concerts, sound design, online music collaboration, audio mixing, networking, digital literacy, blogging, videoconferencing, Facebook, LinkedIn, Hangouts, Wordpress, jamLink, Soundjack, Reaper, flexibility, intuition, integrity, creativity, detail, focus, confidence, optimism. I'm at my best when I'm exploring and implementing better ways to communicate and collaborate, and when I'm showcasing the strengths of colleagues through online storytelling and photography. Experience Windows System Administrator Google June 2015  – Present (3 months) Mountain View, CA IT Security Analyst 3 Stanford University April 2014  –  May 2015  (1 year 2 months) Stanford, CA The information security operations team provides central services to help support other IT units and increased the university's IT security posture. Our services leverage the following products: BigFix, Bit9, Microsoft Enhanced Mitigation Experience Toolkit (EMET), OSSec, Qualys, and Splunk. 
 
My responsibilities include:  
- Plan, implement, and operationalize a university wide Bit9 service that will be offered for all Windows servers and high value Mac and Windows endpoints such as administrative workstations.  
- Co-manage the university’s BigFix service that provided endpoint management to more than 65,000 endpoints. Managing this service includes increasing adoption, patching endpoints, compliance information collection, routine task automation, and empowerment of local IT staff.  
- Investigate suspicious activities of high value assets using tools like Splunk, OSSec, Sysmon, and network flow data.  
- Mentor junior staff to help them be successful in the department and progress in their career. Senior Windows System Administrator and Technical Lead Stanford University November 2013  –  October 2014  (1 year) Stanford, CA Senior Windows System Administrator and Technical Lead for the Infrastructure Delivery Group with responsibilities for the universities central Active Directory, Active Directory Federation Service (ADFS), Windows Certificate Services, Radius (Windows NPS), BigFix, Splunk, and OSSec. 
 
My responsibilities included:  
- Leading a technical team through the incident response and tactical recovery portions of a security breach in the Windows Infrastructure by a known APT group. 
- Leading a team that implemented Splunk for event logging, OSSec for file integrity checking, a new server build process that used trusted server images, and application whitelisting using Microsoft AppLocker. 
- Proposing and implementing a new systems management process for servers using BigFix (IBM Endpoint Manager) to ensure we had a complete server inventory, patch status, and ability to easily patch systems quickly.
